Quantum mechanics is a theory of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. This paper provides a purely categorical characterization of this theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related species of myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the evolution of the Myxozoa and may have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a serious global health problem that has caused more than 50 million cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking IFN signaling. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and the magnitude of the effects depends on the rate of warming. We quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and yield variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We conclude that investments in breeding for heat tolerance are urgently needed.

The coexistence of many species of large mammalian herbivores in the same ecosystem is a major puzzle in ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the degree to which different species partition the food resources of the ecosystem. We show that, despite their size and dietary overlap, different species of large herbivores partition food resources in ways that are not easily predicted from their body size or the proportion of their diet made up of grasses. These results suggest that the coexistence of many species of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the risk of closure is negatively associated with the expected length of the crisis. Moreover, businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern, but the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the formation of the solar system and the early solar system. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for studying the formation of the solar system and the early solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased by a factor of 10. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care. Here, we show that the evolution of care, both allo- and allonursing, is associated with an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother. This increase in energy availability is associated with an increase in the number of offspring produced.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after onset, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-synuclein in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of α-synuclein aggregates and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-synuclein accumulation. This study opens the way to a clinical trial in MSA patients. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between blood and tissue. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and the first line of defense against infection and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources, including the circulatory system, the nervous system, and the immune system. The endothelium is also able to communicate with other cells in the vascular wall and with cells in the surrounding tissue. This communication is essential for the proper functioning of the vascular system and for the maintenance of homeostasis.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data has never been greater. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders in the pandemic response.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the allosteric communication between these two domains. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. This study investigates the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. The results of this study support the hypothesis that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This study also provides a resource for the discovery of novel natural products from anaerobic gut fungi. This work is a step toward understanding the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to influence the health of herbivores and the environment.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality in the development of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, which is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures that are composed of multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene family is one of the largest in the human genome, and the expression of the different hemoglobin genes is regulated in a developmental and tissue-specific manner. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the developing human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key factor in the developmental silencing of the adult hemoglobin genes. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobin disorders and for the development of therapies for such disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), two highly frequent events in cancer, and by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis. This resistance is overcome by inhibition of the mTORC1 signaling pathway, which is activated by mutation of PI3K or PTEN, and by induction of ferroptosis, which is a promising target for cancer therapy. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have a number of side effects. We have identified a mechanism of action of these drugs that may help to develop new drugs with fewer side effects.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems has not been effective in increasing the area of older forests. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The climate of the tropics has a profound influence on the evolution of life on Earth. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows that the climate of the tropics has been far more variable in the past than previously thought, and that the climate of the tropics has been drier in the past than today. This has profound implications for the evolution of life in the tropics.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime has a significant impact on sleep, with participants taking longer to fall asleep, having reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin levels, and later timing of their circadian clock. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is a key event in the Earth’s history, but the cause of the YDB is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. In this study, we show that the osmium isotope ratios of the YDB samples are consistent with the terrestrial origin of osmium. The YDB samples from Pennsylvania have a unique feature of spherules that formed as ejecta from an impact.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species, and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which we manipulated the size of the population of models that participants could learn from. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population did affect the variation in plane performance and the ability to copy the best-adapted plane. These findings suggest that the size of the population may be an important factor in the evolution of cumulative cultural systems.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 increases risk by ∼12-fold. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This difference is due to the different structures of the core materials.

Marijuana is a drug that is widely used, but its effects on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain.

Language is the most complex form of communication. How the human brain processes language is therefore one of the most important and challenging problems in neuroscience. Here, we show that the latest advances in deep learning can predict brain responses to spoken sentences in humans while achieving high accuracy on a language task. Our results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. These findings also suggest that the latest advances in deep learning may be applicable to neuroscience in general.

Deep learning has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many deep learning algorithms are unstable in the sense of numerical analysis. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they exist for a large class of problems. This opens up a new direction in the study of deep learning and opens the door to many applications.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a prime example of the failure of governments to manage a crisis. It has also become a prime example of the failure of scientists to communicate about the crisis. In this paper, we show that the latter failure is rooted in the former. We show that the failure is rooted in the failure of scientists to understand the nature of exponential growth.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which have diverged from a common ancestor. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost this ability. This suggests that M. lepromatosis is a potential pathogen for the nervous system.

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central problem in quantum many-body physics. It is also a fundamental problem in statistical mechanics, as it is the origin of thermodynamics. However, the entanglement dynamics is a nonunitary process, and, therefore, it is not amenable to the standard methods of statistical mechanics. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine is a critical need to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. This vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, generates high levels of spike-specific antibodies, and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. These results support the potential use of this vaccine candidate in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine candidate is currently in clinical development. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. However, this hypothesis is based on indirect evidence, such as the high abundance of rats in plague-affected areas. Here, we present a model for the spread of plague by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the fact that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its control.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not only associated with the evolution of brain mass but also with the evolution of the number of neurons. We also show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain complexity.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the development of new therapies will depend on a better understanding of the molecular events that lead to the transformation of normal cells into cancer cells. In this study, we show that the mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 plays a role in the regulation of metabolism and cell cycle progression.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The process of disassembly is controlled by a family of proteins that are related to each other and to the cytoskeleton-associated protein cofilin. We show that these proteins can sever actin filaments, and we provide a mechanism for how this occurs.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the human history of Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of two continents, Africa and Asia, and that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased manner. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the human history of Madagascar and opens the door to a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. We show that the content of people’s Facebook News Feeds influences their emotions. We find that people who see more positive content in their News Feed become more positive, and people who see more negative content become more negative. This work suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media, and for our understanding of the role of social media in society.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and many modifications of the mRNA sequence can affect translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation.

This paper shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and life satisfaction. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is an opportunistic pathogen that infects patients with compromised immune systems, and it is responsible for a variety of infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and urinary tract infections. The bacterium is also a leading cause of chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients. The mechanisms that the pathogen uses to cause disease are not fully understood. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its pili to sense the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this sensing system is important for the pathogenicity of the bacterium.

The global use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing, and the use of newer-generation insecticides is on the rise. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its effects on surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into wildlife and the reemergence of the virus. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to monitoring the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, biodiversity, and the livelihoods of people living in the areas where they are built. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed. We propose that the industry needs to move away from building large dams and toward smaller, more distributed, and more flexible renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary component of the pathological process. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD cases. Here, we show that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of the inflammatory response in AD, and that this response is not limited to the brain. Our findings suggest that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a critical player in the AD pathogenesis, and may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for most proteins. The folding of a single protein, maltose binding protein, was studied in great detail by a combination of methods, including mass spectrometry. The results show that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, and that the folding pathway is not known for this protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA molecules. However, the cellular response to such stress is characterized by the formation of disulfide bonds, which are known to inactivate the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, a different decapping enzyme, RppH, becomes the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune response is essential for the elimination of infection, it can also contribute to the development of severe sepsis and septic shock. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune response during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonstandard amino acid that can be synthesized from arginine, is a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system evolves in time in such a way that the rate of change of its activity is nearly constant. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, neural networks, combustion, and fluid turbulence. The origin of SOC is not fully understood, but it is believed to be related to the critical behavior of a system. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the electronic bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up a new avenue for tailoring the properties of diamond. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with desired properties. Our work also provides a framework for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of materials. This work can be extended to other materials, and the findings can be used to design materials with desired properties.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new therapeutics. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are highly diverse in sequence and structure. These peptides are expressed in the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula, and are highly active against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and show that the female reproductive tract is a major source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a framework for understanding the molecular interactions between sperm and the female reproductive tract and will be of interest to all reproductive biologists.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. The A1 domain in VWF binds to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches A1 and/or GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common bleeding disorder. The results suggest that the A1 domain is a conformational switch. The mechanism is relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. The results also suggest that the A1 domain is a conformational switch.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the study of the human virome. The database is publicly available, and can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing. The observations show that the ACI process is more complex than previously thought. This finding constitutes substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that this instrument will be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the chemistry of the biosphere, and thus on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred to be linked to the temperature history of the deep interior, and thus to the evolution of the planet. However, the temperature of the surface is difficult to determine directly, and the temperature of the deep interior is even more difficult to determine. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are important for the normal function of cells and the body. Ion channels are also the targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are also the targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are the targets of drugs and toxins.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 1 billion people at risk of infection. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of infection. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the red cell surface and that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the red cell membrane. We show that these changes in the red cell membrane are required for parasite invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has implications for the development of malaria vaccines and therapeutics. (Less)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This work opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond via strain engineering. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with desired properties. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the properties of other materials in the same way. This framework can be used to explore the properties of other materials in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and severity of disease. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on influenza pathogenesis, which may be useful in the development of therapeutic strategies. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence from the bottom up, but there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we show that the brain responds to each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in gamma power, followed by a sudden decrease when the word can be merged into a phrase. This suggests that the brain uses a merge operation to build a tree of phrases. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important pathways in development. It is also involved in the development of cancer. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and two forms of Axin are found in vertebrates. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and that this difference is used to control the activity of the pathway in different tissues.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for its causes has been a major focus of neuroscience. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the most important nutrient for agriculture. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture, and could be used to deliver nitrogen to plants in a sustainable manner. Here, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all made of tissue and are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory system that is not constrained by the body and is extended to its web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, and the spider can remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can also adjust and regenerate the web to suit its needs. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing, the design of acoustic sensors, and the potential of outsourcing and supersizing of sensing. It also opens up new possibilities for the design of acoustic flow detectors and other applications.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

COVID-19 is a pandemic with no end in sight. Vaccines are needed to protect the world, but the current vaccines are expensive and may not be accessible to all. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is easy to express in bacteria, has high affinity for ACE2, and is immunogenic in mice. This variant is also suitable for presentation on a virus-like particle, which can be used to protect hamsters from infection. These findings suggest that this variant could be used in a vaccine or as a component of a vaccine.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of neural crest-derived tissues in children. The molecular mechanisms underlying the development of neuroblastoma are not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like receptors (Alkals) are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish lateral line. We also show that Alkals are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins, which are expressed in the developing nervous system. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK-like receptors in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALs represent potential targets for neuroblastoma therapy.

Yersinia pestis is one of the most devastating pathogens in human history, and its origins are shrouded in mystery. We present a large dataset of Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which reveals a unique evolutionary trajectory for this pathogen. We show that the emergence of Y. pestis from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor was a gradual process, and that the emergence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis occurred later in the Bronze Age. These findings provide insights into the origins of plague and its adaptation to its vector, the flea. This work also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in understanding the origins of pathogens and their adaptation to new environments. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. We found that, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) loss from agricultural lands has been a major concern for decades. In the last 20 y, there has been a growing interest in the potential of soil health management practices to mitigate this loss. However, there is a lack of data on the efficacy of these practices in annual cropping systems on the North American Great Plains. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC and microbial biomass, but that these changes are not sufficient to offset the loss of SOC that has occurred on agricultural lands in the last century. Our results highlight the importance of re-establishing perennial grasslands and integrating livestock to mitigate climate change on the Great Plains.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We used a combination of expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify the key factors contributing to spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates the risk of viruses from animals to humans. This tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform the development of effective strategies for prevention and control of future zoonotic threats.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red nectar color is a convergently evolved trait that is likely to be favored in plants that depend on animals for reproduction.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the modern European genetic landscape. However, the processes that led to the current genetic structure have been largely unknown. Here, we present a study of the genetic structure of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic structure of the population was shaped by a combination of migrations from outside Europe and local processes. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the history of Europe and the processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origins of MERS-CoV and other zoonotic coronaviruses. They also suggest that the use of DPP4-

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We show that vector-borne pathogens are the most common clinical category, and that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, are also detected. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using mNGS in resource-scarce settings, and the potential for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can inform rapid public health response. This study is a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, and the potential for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can inform rapid public health response.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for eukaryotic DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate other RNA molecules, but the process is inefficient. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules with high fidelity and efficiency. This polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA templates in the absence of proteins, and it can amplify short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in a form of PCR that is catalyzed by RNA. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can serve as a primitive form of life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of neighborhoods in determining their future physical appearance. These results have implications for urban planning and policy, as well as for the study of urban change more broadly.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results of this study provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability to control copper levels in the cell is therefore an important aspect of fungal physiology. In this study, we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the binding and sequestration of copper. This is a novel function for a fungal natural product, and the existence of the xan cluster in other filamentous fungi suggests a role for this mechanism in the control of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes.

The formation of silica in the martian environment is a key to understanding the origin of the martian surface and its water history. The chemistry of the aqueous fluids and the conditions of their precipitation are important to the understanding of the evolution of the martian surface. The chemistry of the aqueous fluids and the conditions of their precipitation are important to the understanding of the evolution of the martian surface.

Frost events are a major source of crop and animal losses, and their impact is expected to increase in a warmer world. However, the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary adaptations of plants and animals to them are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out timing of trees, and that this association is likely to be driven by the evolutionary history of the species. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are likely to be insufficient to cope with increasing frost events in the future. Our findings highlight the need for more research on the impact of frost events on ecosystems and the development of frost-resistant cultivars.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. We have developed a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will facilitate the development of new therapies for ALS.

The role of the microbiome in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors is a topic of increasing interest. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its transmission. We identify a protein that is expressed by the pathogen and that alters the composition of the gut microbiota. This protein, which is homologous to antifreeze proteins, binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiome of their vectors. They also suggest that targeting this process may be a strategy for controlling the transmission of infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals, and the study of their evolution is a key component of understanding their biology and diversity. This study describes a new species of early bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of these colors are associated with the presence of specific molecules. For example, the presence of phytochromes in plants is associated with the red color of the leaves. Here, we show that the presence of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) is associated with the presence of a specific protein, which we describe as biliverdin-binding serpins (BBS). We show that BBSs are similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional basis for the evolution of green coloration in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of metastasis. We have identified a mechanism by which hypoxia induces the expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a BCSC marker. ALKBH5 is a m6A demethylase, and we have shown that ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner. This study provides a mechanism by which hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, and suggests that ALKBH5 may be a potential target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these early pocket Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, but the timing of the event is well constrained by the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary. Here we present a refined age model for the extinction and its aftermath, which will allow a more precise evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will in turn allow a more refined evaluation of the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results will have implications for our understanding of the evolution of the biosphere.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract. Although the exact pathogenesis of IBD is not fully understood, it is believed to be associated with the imbalance between the immune response and the intestinal epithelium. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal epithelium by regulating the activity of the nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) signaling pathway. We also found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) regulates the expression of NF-κB target genes in intestinal epithelial cells, which is important for the control of intestinal inflammation. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. The structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with ACE2 provides a basis for understanding the mechanism of action of the vaccine and therapeutics currently in development.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 83.08 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical behavior of atoms is one of the most fundamental properties of matter. It is also one of the most complex, and it is not well understood. In this work, we propose a simple and powerful way to understand the chemical behavior of atoms as a function of pressure. We show that the chemical behavior of atoms can be described by two simple properties, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We show that these properties change with pressure, and we show that they can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. This work opens the door to a new understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms and to the prediction of exotic chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the effect of fire on climate change is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, such as population growth and migration, can reduce fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. This effect is most effective under lower emission scenarios, and it is important to consider the role of human demography in climate mitigation strategies. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a model for studying the evolution of mutualism. We show that the squid provides a single glycan to the symbiont, which is required for the maturation of the symbiosis and for the maintenance of the symbiont population. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the metabolic products to modify the conditions of the symbiosis. This study suggests that the provision of nutrients to the symbionts of animal hosts may be a common mechanism for regulating the activities of symbioses.

Text data is ubiquitous, but it is often difficult to analyze. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We apply this method to the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. We find that the system is underreporting female victims, and that the topics in the narratives about violence are gendered. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to any domain, and can be used to identify latent patterns in text data. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that caused the pandemic, for at least 15 y before the first European outbreaks. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe from Asia, rather than establishing itself in Europe from a single introduction. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a keystone species in the marine ecosystem, and their loss has significant ecological and economic consequences. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids, and the first report of a densovirus in the marine environment.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can block IL-1 signaling and suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling may be a potential target for the treatment of other diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to investigate the origin and the settlement history of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people have a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, but that the settlement history of Madagascar is more complex. We find that the settlement of Madagascar was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across the island, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar was the result of multiple independent events. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar and will help to improve the conservation of the biodiversity of the island. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the protein interacts with the enzyme that catalyzes the final step in glycerol metabolism and that the protein interferes with the activity of the enzyme. The RNA also interferes with the activity of a second small RNA, suggesting that the two RNAs compete for the same target. This is an example of a mechanism that has evolved to control the expression of genes that are important for survival in changing environments.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules.
